H0.text: An air mass is warmer at the leading edge and cooler at the trailing edge.

H1.text: An air mass has similar temperature and moisture properties throughout it, which is true regarding the properties of an air mass.

H2.text: An air mass is cooler near the edges and has greater moisture near the center.

H3.text: An air mass has greater moisture near the edges and is cooler near the center.

A4.text: Heat from underlying warmer waters can significantly modify an air mass over distances as short as 35 kilometres (22 mi) to 40 kilometres (25 mi).

A5.text: Subsidence will generally dry out an air mass by adiabatic, or compressional, heating.

A6.text: Temperature variations on land are greater than on water.
